courses.name: The City Where Movies Are Made

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course, first-year students will be introduced to film culture in Toronto from a variety of angles, including: a history of the city onscreen (both as itself and as a popular shooting location for American productions); an account of major Toronto filmmaking sites and institutions; introductions to local directors and producers; and overviews of contemporary local film festival culture (TIFF and beyond) as well as the city’s film-critical community. Through a combination of lectures, screenings, field trips and special guest speakers, the students will be moved to consider both the vitality of Toronto’s film scene as well as its connections to other aspects of the city. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: The City Where Movies Are Made
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information, please visit: http://innis.utoronto.ca/academic-programs/one/

Delivery Instructions

Delivery Method: Dual Delivery (HyFlex)

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the concept of the city as a creative environment promoting not only growth and wealth but also social justice, equality, cooperation, and civility. Students will learn to build their own blog to help them to observe, interpret, and reflect upon the process of urban interaction and the relationship between creativity and justice. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Blogging the Just City
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information, please visit: http://innis.utoronto.ca/academic-programs/one/

Delivery Instructions

This course will be held online and will have both asynchronous and synchronous elements. For example, some lectures may be delivered asynchronously, while discussions and guest presentations may be held synchronously. Field trips will be held, if public health guidelines allow, and alternate activities will be provided for those who are not able to participate in person. It is recommended that students have access to a microphone in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Telling the Stories of the City: Writing Creative Non-Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to creative writing techniques and the personal essay form through which students will explore and develop their conscious connection to the natural-urban landscape. The course will include activities such as field trips, readings, interviews, and journaling to generate the material for personal essays on engagement with nature in the city. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Telling the Stories of the City: Writing Creative Non-Fiction
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information, please visit: http://innis.utoronto.ca/academic-programs/one/

Delivery Instructions

Lecture slides will be posted each week. Recordings of classes will be available upon request. Students may at times be asked to view content prior to class. Students will need to have both a microphone and camera to participate in frequent class and small group discussions.

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on essay writing designed to equip students with the skills required to write on different subjects and in a variety of different genres (including critical analysis, the narrative essay, and argumentative writing). By unpacking the stages of the writing process, this course helps students develop research, critical reading, planning, organization, writing, editing, and proofreading skills.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing Essays

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

LEC0101: Online lectures will be recorded and available on Quercus but Q & A/discussion will not likely be recorded (so students who can't access class synchronously will be affected). Students will not have to watch video content before the class (but they will likely have the option of watching the lecture portion either 24 hours before or during class). Microphone and camera will be helpful.

TUT0101 and TUT0201: Online tutorials will not be recorded (so students who can't access them synchronously will be affected). Students will have to watch video content from the INI103 lecture before each tutorial. Microphone and camera will be required.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 25, 2020: Section Cancelled.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 25, 2020: Section Cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on essay writing designed to equip students with the skills required to write on different subjects and in a variety of different genres (including critical analysis, the narrative essay, and argumentative writing). By unpacking the stages of the writing process, this course helps students develop research, critical reading, planning, organization, writing, editing, and proofreading skills.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing Essays

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

LEC2000 and LEC2001 are restricted to students in the Transitional Year Programme and do not have tutorials.

Delivery Instructions

Delivery Instructions for LEC0101 and LEC9101: Students will be able to access recordings of online lectures, but not tutorials. A microphone and webcam would be helpful for class participation. Students will not be expected to view video content prior to a class.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces the fundamentals of report writing within an interdisciplinary context. This writing intensive course focuses on improving writing skills appropriate to report writing genres. Informal, formal, research, and professional workplace reports are examined in terms of purpose, audience, structure, style, persuasive strategies, and use of visual rhetoric (tables, charts, graphs). This course also examines qualitative and quantitative research methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing Reports

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course is a combination of asynchronous and synchronous learning. Each week, students will be given a two hour recorded lecture well in advance of the lecture. They will be asked to attend the weekly synchronous meeting as well. Tutorials will be held at key points throughout the term as noted in the syllabus; students are asked to take note of tutorial hours. All synchronous lecture meetings will be recorded. Tutorial meetings shall not be recorded and attendance shall be taken.

courses.name: Writing Literary Journalism: Telling the Stories of the City

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to literary journalism, in which students study the craft of storytelling along with interviewing, reporting, and the journalist’s ethical stance. Guest speakers, field trips, writing activities and course readings will help students engage deeply with their environment and develop the skills and sensitivity required for literary reporting. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing Literary Journalism: Telling the Stories of the City
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information, please visit: http://innis.utoronto.ca/academic-programs/one/

Delivery Instructions

Students will not be able to access recordings from the online-synchronous parts of the course, but will be expected to access and view asynchronous video content prior to each class.

LEC0101 (In-Person): Students in the in-person section of the class are not required to bring a computer to class.

LEC9101 (Online): Students in the online portion of the class will need a computer with Internet access, a webcam and microphone in order to participate verbally in synchronous class discussions.

courses.name: Hoboes, Geniuses and Immigrants: Otherness in Contemporary Culture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 31, 2020: Course cancelled.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 31, 2020: Course cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: Hoboes, geniuses, and immigrants all share a sense of Otherness in terms of their identity because they are different from the norm. This course analyzes the factors that create the sense of Otherness in an individual. Can Otherness be chosen as an identity or is it imposed by society? What conditions make Otherness a positive or negative experience? What is the distinction between difference and Otherness? Instances of Otherness both negative and positive are analyzed in contemporary novels and films. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hoboes, Geniuses and Immigrants: Otherness in Contemporary Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information on Innis First Year Foundation (FYF) Seminars, visit: https://innis.utoronto.ca/new-students/preparing/first-year-foundation-seminars/

courses.name: Theories of Rhetoric: A Brief History of Persuasion

cmCourseInfo.description: The history of rhetoric, the philosophical art of persuasion, is a complex one bound up with the histories of philosophy, literature, and religion, the rise and fall of empires, and the emergence of modern science and media technology. We will examine the development of rhetoric over time, from the roots of the discipline in classical antiquity to the genesis of modern and postmodern rhetoric, including the New Rhetoric. We will then focus on contemporary rhetorical currents in language philosophy, gender studies, critical race studies, and affect theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories of Rhetoric: A Brief History of Persuasion

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be able to access recordings of online lectures. A microphone and webcam would be helpful for class participation. Students will not be expected to view video content prior to a class.

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to teach students to write persuasively and to recognize persuasive strategies at work in writing they analyze. Classical rhetorical terms, elements of style, and modes of argument are central to the course. Assignments include a rhetorical analysis, in-class close reading exercises, and a term essay. Readings include prose from a variety of disciplines, excluding fiction and poetry. Students who enrol in the course must demonstrate competence in the English language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations of Written Discourse

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Zoom recordings of the entire three-hour lecture will be available to students to view asynchronously after the scheduled class. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to teach students to write persuasively and to recognize persuasive strategies at work in writing they analyze. Classical rhetorical terms, elements of style, and modes of argument are central to the course. Assignments include a rhetorical analysis, in-class close reading exercises, and a term essay. Readings include prose from a variety of disciplines, excluding fiction and poetry. Students who enrol in the course must demonstrate competence in the English language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Foundations of Written Discourse

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Zoom recordings of the entire three-hour lecture will be available to students to view asynchronously after the scheduled class. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: By exploring different popular culture phenomena such as the emergence of hiphop in the Bronx, Batman's Gotham, and Nollywood, this course works to examine the contributions of popular culture in shaping our understandings of cities (as well as providing different perspectives of the city and the urban experience than is generally captured in scholarly/academic literature). Popular culture becomes a vehicle by which we will explore different aspects of urban life and urban representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cities in Popular Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded. Students will not be expected to view videos prior to class time. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and webcam in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies I: Theoretical Foundations of City Building

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on the theoretical foundations of urbanization, urban change, and city building, with particular attention on global urban growth, history of contemporary urbanization, urban planning, governance, built form, and economic development. These topics are explored through a multidisciplinary lens, with an emphasis on understanding urban transitions over time and their meaning for contemporary urban experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies I: Theoretical Foundations of City Building
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 4.0 FCEs, including 1.0 FCEs from one of the following four course groups. Economics: ECO101H1, ECO102H1, ECO105Y1; Geography: GGR101H1, GGR107H1, GGR112H1, GGR124H1; Political Science: POL101Y1, POL101H1, POL106H1, POL107H1, POL109H1, POL214Y1; Sociology: SOC100H1, SOC150H1.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded. Students will not be expected to view videos prior to class time. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and webcam in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies II: Urban Challenges and Theoretical Application

cmCourseInfo.description: Cities are centres of innovation and creative energy, but they also face significant and pressing challenges. This course explores various urban issues including inequality, eroding infrastructure, and concerns arising from globalization, while also examining the ways in which municipal governments and urban citizens are imagining and implementing potential solutions to these challenges.
cmCourseInfo.title: A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies II: Urban Challenges and Theoretical Application

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be recorded. Recordings will be available for asynchronous viewing.

courses.name: Strategic Writing in Business and the Professions: Theory and Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: Aims to teach students to recognize the rhetoric of the professional workplace and to communicate strategically and ethically using written and oral discourse appropriate to business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central component of the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Strategic Writing in Business and the Professions: Theory and Practice

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Please note that Rotman Commerce students cannot enrol in INI300H1. Rotman Commerce students should instead enrol in INI302H1.

Delivery Instructions

An asynchronous, two-hour-long narrated lecture will be posted online well in advance of the scheduled class meeting. Students are expected to listen to the lecture, take notes, complete the exercises assigned each, and come to our class meetings with any questions. The synchronous portion of our course content is held from 2:00 - 4:00 p.m. on Thursdays. The synchronous component will be recorded. Students should have a microphone in order to participate in discussions verbally. Alternatively, students may also participate by using the text chat function. Please note, attendance shall be taken during all synchronous classes.

courses.name: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce students

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed for and restricted to undergraduates in Rotman Commerce. Assignments and course aims reflect the learning goals of the Rotman Commerce program. This course focuses on critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and the rhetoric of the world of business. The theory and practice of written and oral communication are also central. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central pedagogical tool.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce students

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

An asynchronous, two-hour-long narrated lecture will be posted online well in advance of the scheduled class meeting. Students are expected to listen to the lecture, take notes, and come to our class meetings with any questions. The synchronous lecture portion of our course content be held from 3:00 - 4:00 p.m. on Mondays; tutorials will also be synchronous and conducted during your regularly scheduled tutorial meetings. The synchronous component will be recorded. Students should have a microphone in order to participate in discussions verbally. Alternatively, students may also participate by using the text chat function. Please note, attendance shall be taken during all synchronous classes.

courses.name: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce students

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed for and restricted to undergraduates in Rotman Commerce. Assignments and course aims reflect the learning goals of the Rotman Commerce program. This course focuses on critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and the rhetoric of the world of business. The theory and practice of written and oral communication are also central. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central pedagogical tool.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce students

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The course is a combination of asynchronous and synchronous learning. Each week, students will be given a two hour recorded lecture well in advance of the lecture. They will be asked to attend the weekly synchronous meeting as well. Tutorials will be held at key points throughout the term as noted in the syllabus; students are asked to take note of tutorial hours. All synchronous lecture meetings will be recorded. Tutorial meetings shall not be recorded and attendance shall be taken.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the profound impact of digital media on contemporary culture and discourse. Students will explore recent currents in rhetoric and digital media. Students will investigate the rhetorical operation of digital media in domains ranging from academia to politics to popular culture. The class will analyze the role of rhetorical principles, such as persuasion and identification, in a diverse array of online discourse such as discussion forums, social media, and the blogosphere.
cmCourseInfo.title: Digital Rhetoric

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be able to access recordings of online lectures. A microphone and webcam would be helpful for class participation. Students will not be expected to view video content prior to a class.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to professional editorial conventions at two later stages of the editorial process. Both stages require analytical skills and sentence expertise. Through stylistic editing, students learn how to improve a writer’s literary style; through copy editing, they learn how to ensure both accuracy and consistency (editorial style).
cmCourseInfo.title: Stylistic Editing and Copy Editing

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and a camera so that they can take part in some online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This workshop course examines methodological approaches to literary fiction from the perspective of the creator. Through course readings, discussion, and creative writing assignments, student writers will learn how prose writers combine stylistic techniques, point-of-view, setting, character, scenes, and structure to produce literary effects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Creative Writing
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Experience or strong interest in writing fiction.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture will be available for students to view asynchronously. Most class activities will occur synchronously in person at the scheduled course time. Students will not be expected to screen lectures before class. For students in LEC9101: A microphone and webcam are required for every class.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces professional editorial conventions at two early stages of the editorial process. Both stages require editors to think critically and creatively as they assess content, organization, and argument. Students learn how to analyze and evaluate these elements, envision possible improvements, and explain these suggestions persuasively.
cmCourseInfo.title: Developmental and Substantive Editing

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Students are not expected to view lecture material before class. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: How do power and dominance consolidate in urban settings? How do individuals and communities contest this consolidation, and claim spaces and rights in the city? These questions will be taken up through a range of critical approaches, including Indigenous, critical race feminist, political economy, queer, and anarchist perspectives. Students will have the opportunity to carry out interview-based research on an issue of equality and social justice that matters to them.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Approaches in Urban Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be recorded. Recordings will be available for asynchronous viewing.

cmCourseInfo.description: A prominent thesis in the fields of planning and economic geography is that the presence of creative occupations in a city correlates positively with the overall health of urban regions. This course will investigate the nature of this link from theoretical and empirical perspectives and examine its potential usefulness in a planning/policy context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Creative Cities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

An asynchronous, two hour long lecture will be posted online well in advance of the scheduled class meeting. Students are expected to view video content prior to our scheduled class meeting on Mondays. The synchronous course component will be held during the scheduled class time for tutorials and online quizzes (every 2 weeks). The synchronous component will be recorded. Students should have a microphone in order to participate in discussions verbally. Alternatively, students may also participate using the text chat function.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 12, 2021: Meeting Day changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 12, 2021: Meeting Day changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will focus on an examination of the immediate difficulties facing Toronto and by extension all Canadian cities. Instruction will consist of a combination of lectures by the instructor and by noted experts/practitioners in a range of topic areas including urban governance, finance, planning, environmental sustainability and social welfare.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Contemporary Urban Problems

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture will also be available for students to view asynchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Focus on the impact of increased economic inequality and economic polarization trends that are reshaping Canada's metropolitan areas, changing neighbourhoods, and affecting the lives of our diverse urban population. Using the Toronto area as an example, students explore the consequences of these trends and the implications for public policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Divided City / United City
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
INI235Y1

Distribution Requirement Status: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will not be available for students to view asynchronously. Lectures will be available only as online synchronous and in person at their scheduled times. Students will not be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in the online course in order to ask questions and make comments.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides students an opportunity to craft and initiate an Urban Studies capstone research project. Students will gain knowledge, experience and insight in utilizing qualitative research methods including interviewing, focus groups, observational analysis and other techniques. Seminars and assignments focus on the application of qualitative methods to each student’s selected urban research question.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Studies Research Seminar I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will not be expected to view videos prior to class time, and lectures will not be recorded. They must attend the class online in real time. Tutorials (attendance optional) will take place fully online. Tutorials will be live-streamed, however, tutorials will not be recorded.  It is required that students have a computer with a microphone and webcam in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, students explore topics of their own choice and design their own research projects for a course not otherwise available within the Faculty. The student should submit a detailed proposal and a letter of support from the supervisor by June 1 for Y and F courses and by September 1 for S courses. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Normally requires completion of 15.0 full-course equivalents with 3.3 CGPA and permission of the Innis College Vice-Principal.

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

Open only to students who are completing the Minor Program in Writing and Rhetoric Program. Applications should be submitted to the Program Director by June 1 for a Fall session course or by November 1 for a Spring session course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

courses.name: Special Topics in Writing and Rhetoric

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: The Politics and Rhetoric of Truth – Popular and Disciplinary Discourses Across Time

sections.name: LEC9101
sections.subTitle: The Politics and Rhetoric of Truth – Popular and Disciplinary Discourses Across Time

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminars in special topics designed for students who are completing the Minor Program in Writing and Rhetoric.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Writing and Rhetoric

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Course description for Winter 2021: This course will examine how discourses and rhetoric of truth, truth claims, and epistemologies have changed over time in Western thought and culture. The survey will include examination of how scholarly disciplines such as history, science, and philosophy, and feminist theory have developed their conceptions of truth claims, evidence, and epistemology. We will explore popular conceptions of truth, in the context of contemporary journalism, media, and digital media politics, from the rise of photojournalism to deep fakes. We will examine such events as epidemics, Truth and Reconciliation in Canada, slave narratives, and legal conceptions of testimony. We will also consider how binaries of reason and emotion shape perceptions and experiences of truth in more subjective sense, attending to questions of trust, belief, and skepticism. Readings will draw on thinkers including Hayden White, Donna Haraway, Sandra Harding, Karl Popper, Jeff Corntassel, Paulette Regan, Frederick Douglass, Primo Levi, and Shoshana Felman.

Delivery Instructions

(Note: The prerequisite will be waived for Winter 2021. Permission of the instructor is not required to enrol in this class) It is required that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Students may be asked to view movies or films in preparation for classes.

cmCourseInfo.description: We will read and write a variety of texts focused on effecting social change. Students will be encouraged to engage with different theories of social change and an array of writing genres, ranging from journalism to critical theory to fiction. Ultimately, students will focus on one or several key social issues that they wish to write about for their final project.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing for Social Change

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online lectures will likely be recorded and available on Quercus but Q & A/discussion will not likely be recorded (so students who can't access class synchronously will be affected). Students will not have to watch video content before the class (but they will likely have the option of watching the lecture portion either 24 hours before or during class). Microphone and webcam will be required.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: August 21, 2020: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: From time to time, the Urban Studies Program organizes community outreach and information sessions. At the discretion of the Director, students may enroll in a special topics course and investigate these issues more deeply under the supervision of an agreeable faculty member. Proposals including a letter from an agreeable faculty member should be submitted to the Director by June 1 for a Fall or Year-long course, or by November 1 for a Spring course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Urban Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment in a major or specialist program in Urban Studies.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: INI235Y1, completion of research design and research methods courses, and suitable 4th-year standing (in terms of credits completed) in an aligned social science discipline.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is restricted to students who have been accepted to the School of Cities Multidisciplinary Urban Capstone Project for Fall/Winter 2020-2021. Applications are no longer being accepted for the 2020-2021 cycle. For more information on this course, please visit: https://www.schoolofcities.utoronto.ca/urban-pilot-lab/multidisciplinary-urban-capstone-project

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Racial Capitalism, Settler Colonialism, Urban Infrastructure

sections.name: LEC9101
sections.subTitle: Racial Capitalism, Settler Colonialism, Urban Infrastructure

cmCourseInfo.description: Special topics courses are offered periodically for senior students in the Urban Studies Program. Offerings in any given year will depend on program priorities, availability of specialized expertise and funding. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Urban Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment in a major or specialist program in Urban Studies.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: INI235Y1, completion of research design and research methods courses, and suitable 4th-year standing (in terms of credits completed) in an aligned social science discipline.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Course Description for Winter 2021: In this course, we will consider how the everyday work of racial capitalism and settler colonialism has always been grounded through infrastructures: or, the geographically extensive systems that build, sustain, and manage human life. These entangled infrastructural projects have shaped urban life across Turtle Island from the early 20th century onwards. Drawing from the work of Ruth Wilson Gilmore, Deborah Cowen, Cedric Robinson, and Audra Simpson, this course seeks to better understand how the US and Canadian settler states have leveraged infrastructure – in both its obvious and less obvious forms – as a way of responding to the “urban panics” engendered by the evolving geographies of immigration, race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, and class. To this end, we will explore a diversity of topics, including gentrification, broken windows policing, diasporic (sub)urbanisms, and urban poverty, to name only a few examples. We will also attend to the ways in which urban infrastructures have always doubled as a terrain for radical struggle, resistance and refusal. We will conclude this course by reflecting on the ongoing and urgent political need to work towards the abolition of carceral and settler urban regimes in all of their various guises and dimensions.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded. Students will not be expected to view videos prior to class time. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and webcam in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to allow strong students in the Major and Specialist programs to extend a piece of urban research under the supervision of a faculty member from any aligned department. Choice of ‘H’ or ‘Y’ session pursuant to the scope of the research envisioned, the proposed supervisor’s assessment of depth of the inquiry, and the approval of the program director. Proposals, including a letter from an agreeable supervisor should be submitted to the program director by June 1 for a Fall or Year session course and by November 1 for a Spring session course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Urban Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: INI235H1, INI236H1, completion of research design and research methods courses, 14 FCEs in an aligned social science program. Enrolment in the Urban Studies Major or Specialist programs.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For independent research courses, please contact Urban Studies Program Coordinator, Jannie Chien at programs.innis@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Delivery Method: Online – Asynchronous

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Urban Experiential Learning in Toronto & the GTA

cmCourseInfo.description: A method of studying city issues that combines readings, seminar discussions, and field trips with an 8 hour / week internship in the office of a municipal politician, local government, or non-profit organization. Readings focus on community development, urban planning, economic development and local governance. Students must fill out a ballot for the course (available by contacting the Urban Studies Program Office) by June 1st. Enrolment in this course is competitive and at the discretion of the Urban Studies Director and/or course instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Urban Experiential Learning in Toronto & the GTA
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: INI235H1, INI236H1. Priority is given to students enrolled in the Urban Studies Minor, Major, or Specialist Programs. However, consideration may be given to students with suitable course background as determined by the Program Director. Note: INI437Y1 cannot be taken concurrently with JGI450Y1.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For more information about this course, please contact Urban Studies Program Coordinator, Jannie Chien at programs.innis@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Students will not be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and webcam in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Cities and Mega-events: Place-making, Contestation and Urban Citizenship

cmCourseInfo.description: Mega-events, like the Olympics, give cities the opportunity to showcase themselves to the world, but the production of television-friendly urban images do much to obscure the processes, compromises and social consequences in host cities. These events are powerful tools for city branding. They are also potential opportunities for social movements and other groups and individuals to highlight their own sets of concerns. This course will explore the challenges and opportunities that cities face in hosting such events.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cities and Mega-events: Place-making, Contestation and Urban Citizenship
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI430H1 (topic of same name in 2013-14), INI332H1, INI432H1 (2016)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded. Students will not be expected to view videos prior to class time. Tutorials (attendance optional) will take place fully online. Tutorials will be live-streamed, however, tutorials will not be recorded. It is required that students have a computer with a microphone and webcam in order to participate in online activities.
